Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Development and Application of Distributable, Internet Accessible, Interactive Medical Imaging Teaching Software and Dynamic Tracking System

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is establishing a contemporary teaching method and interactive learning environment for use in medical image education. The project is developing medical imaging teaching software (MITS) and an interactive, internet-based, dynamic assessment tracking system (DATS); producing an innovative assessment model that is iterative and aids in student learning of design concepts. The project is a joint effort by University of Miami (lead), Florida Atlantic University, Florida International University, and Miami Dade College. The effort includes four specific tasks: 1) complete development of MITS utilizing efforts from participating institutions; 2) implementation of DATS as an online evaluation database; 3) comprehensive multi-level evaluations using the embedded iterative evaluation design framework, through reflective synthesis feedback loops (to monitor, direct and correct the development and application); and 4) multi-level dissemination in local, regional, state-wide, and national ranges. The products (MITS/DATS) are directly affecting the delivery of medical imaging education, particularly for those beginning to create medical imaging curricula. The four school collaboration is ensuring that the research is addressing diverse student populations, diverse class sizes and teaching environments, differing course settings involving more than 80 related courses, and a broad community engaged in student training and faculty development activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ultimate goal of this project is to establish a contemporary teaching method and interactive learning environment in the area of medical imaging education for engineering and science undergraduates, particularly for biomedical engineering students. Biomedical engineering (BME) has developed as an interdisciplinary engineering training area in the last 30 years and has become one of the most rapidly growing engineering majors in recent years. As a key component in this field, Medical Imaging, which combines physics, mathematics, electrical engineering and computer engineering, provides students with a broad view of an integration of different technologies applied to biology and medicine. Medical imaging education is a branch of STEM education. The objectives of the project are 1) to develop and complete the sharable, distributable, sustainable and upgradeable Medical Imaging Teaching Software (MITS) and its associated Dynamic Assessment Tracking System (DATS), 2) to scale up the applications from three participating institutions to a national dissemination with a variety of teaching/learning settings, and 3) to study the effectiveness and efficiency by using the developed web-based medical imaging courseware.  

Intellectual Merits: Through the efforts from three participating institutions, an online MITS/DATS system has been created and available to public http://mis.eng.miami.edu. The MITS/DATS system benefits students, instructors, and medical imaging education community by the following features: 1) The interactive design conveys dynamic explanations for physics concepts and engineering principles through animations and simulations and the module-based design fits various classes for different curriculum settings; 2) Independent development and application in each participating institution create a sustainable model for future adoption even after the funding cycle; and 3) Instructors and students are provided with a step-by-step teaching/learning environment and a dynamic feedback system managed by an Internet accessible database.

Broader Impacts: 1) The product (MITS/DATS) of this project, subscribed by many institutions, has directly affected the way of delivering medical imaging education, particularly for those start-up medical imaging curricula. The participating institutions, Florida Atlantic University, Florida International University, and University of Miami, have the environment of diverse student populations (a total of more than 1000 undergraduates with minority and women from Minority or Hispanic-serving institutions), class sizes and teaching environments, course settings (more than 80 related courses), and student training focuses. In addition, more than 20 other domestic or international institutions have also subscribed the MITS/DATS system as online courseware or reference. 2) Three national workshops were hosted by the PI at the University of Miami. More than 40 faculty members, post doctors, graduate students from more than different institutions attended the workshops. An internal faculty development session was hosted by the College of Engineering at the University of Miami.
